ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: The distress I feel about my gender varies based on how I am treated by others.
I fear that other people will never see my true gender.
I feel relief when people correctly see my gender.
I feel upset when people invalidate my gender.
The stress I experience related to my gender varies based on who I am with.
Thinking about parts of my body that do not reflect my gender causes me anxiety.
The distress I feel about my gender differs based on who is misgendering me.
The distress I feel about my gender varies from day to day.
When my appearance matches my gender, my distress is lifted
I wonder if I am ''trans enough'' or ''nonbinary enough''.
I feel pressure to hide my gender in social settings.
I feel trapped by other people's views of my gender.
I feel disconnected from parts of my body that do not reflect my gender.
I am uncomfortable around others when my gender is perceived incorrectly.
I feel relief when my gender is validated.
The distress I feel about my gender varies based on how hostile or transphobic the environment is.
I am uncomfortable with parts of my body that don't feel aligned with my gender.
I feel relief when I wear things that express my gender (e.g., clothes, accessories) .
I am frustrated when people refuse to acknowledge my gender.
I feel uneasy that my primary sex characteristics (e.g., genitals) do not match my gender.
I worry that others do not believe that my gender is valid.
I feel uncomfortable when others use gendered language that doesn't fit me (e.g., saying ma'am or sir when greeting me).
Being accepted as my gender relieves some of my gender-related distress.
I feel uncomfortable when others expect me to act in ways that do not match my gender.
Seeing parts of my body that don't reflect my gender causes emotional discomfort.
